problems.question: What is electrolysis?
options: An electrolytic cell operating under no external power
Using electrical energy to drive a non-spontaneous chemical reaction
problems.hint: Electrolysis consumes energy rather than producing it.
problems.detailed: Electrolysis is the process in which electrical energy is used to force a chemical reaction that would not occur spontaneously. It requires a power source. Answer: C.
problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna

problems.question: At which electrode does reduction occur during electrolysis?
problems.hint: Reduction means gain of electrons; that occurs at the negative electrode.
problems.detailed: In electrolysis, electrons are supplied from the external circuit and arrive at the cathode, where reduction (gain of electrons) occurs. Answer: B.
problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna

problems.question: Which ions migrate to the cathode during electrolysis?
problems.hint: Cathode is negatively charged, so positive ions are attracted.
problems.detailed: Cations are positively charged and are attracted to the negative electrode (cathode), where they are reduced. Answer: A.
problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna

problems.question: In the electrolysis of aqueous \(\ce{NaCl}\), which gas is released at the anode?
problems.hint: Chloride ions are easier to oxidize than water in brine solution.
problems.detailed: In aqueous \(\ce{NaCl}\) electrolysis, chloride ions are oxidized at the anode to form chlorine gas: \(\ce{2Cl- -> Cl2 + 2e-}\). So chlorine is released. Answer: C.
problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna

problems.question: In electrolysis of molten \(\ce{CuSO4}\) using copper electrodes, what happens at the anode?
options: Copper ions gain electrons and deposit as copper metal
Sulphate ions are reduced to sulphur dioxide
problems.hint: At the anode, oxidation occurs; the electrode dissolves into ions.
problems.detailed: In molten \(\ce{CuSO4}\) electrolysis using copper electrodes, the anode dissolves: \(\ce{Cu(s) -> Cu^{2+} + 2e-}\). Thus copper metal is oxidized into ions. Answer: B.
problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
